qas.question: How many Byzantine mosaics survived past the 8th century?
The mosaic in the church in Thessaloniki is know as what?
Why was Christ in majesty protected from the iconoclastic destruction?
When were the panels in the Hagios Demetrios Church created?
What is common about the surviving mosaics from the 7th-9th centuries?

context: <a0_0>Very few<a0_0/> early Byzantine mosaics survived the Iconoclastic destruction of the 8th century. Among the rare examples are the 6th-century <a1_0>Christ in majesty (or Ezekiel's Vision)<a1_0/> mosaic in the apse of the Church of Hosios David in Thessaloniki that was <a2_0>hidden behind mortar<a2_0/> during those dangerous times. Nine mosaic panels in the Hagios Demetrios Church, which were made <a3_0>between 634 and 730<a3_0/>, also escaped destruction. Unusually <a4_0>almost all represent Saint Demetrius<a4_0/> of Thessaloniki, often with suppliants before him.
